channel.title: Comments on: Rhino Mocks: Recursion And Multiple Return Values From Stubs

item.title: By: Jeffrey Bridgman
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Bridgman
item.description: Have you used this stuff recently? You say "It’s important to note that if you do not specify the number of times to repeat for the first stub, then the second stub will simply overwrite the first one" but experience has been otherwise (the first one will be repeated every time unless I put .Repeat.Any() on the second one).
item.content:encoded: Have you used this stuff recently? You say “It’s important to note that if you do not specify the number of times to repeat for the first stub, then the second stub will simply overwrite the first one” but experience has been otherwise (the first one will be repeated every time unless I put .Repeat.Any() on the second one).

item.title: By: derick.bailey
item.dc:creator: derick.bailey
item.description: @Erik - yes, but it would take somewhere in the neighborhood of 32,000 times to cause that. the typical use case for switching between login and launch view in our app is maybe a few times on average. even if they did that a few hundred times, it wouldn't be a big deal.
item.content:encoded: @Erik – yes, but it would take somewhere in the neighborhood of 32,000 times to cause that. the typical use case for switching between login and launch view in our app is maybe a few times on average. even if they did that a few hundred times, it wouldn’t be a big deal.

item.title: By: Erik
item.dc:creator: Erik
item.description: This is off topic, but isn't it theoretically possible for someone to flip back and forth between views enough to exhaust the stack?
item.content:encoded: This is off topic, but isn’t it theoretically possible for someone to flip back and forth between views enough to exhaust the stack?
